properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect through Sunday morning. Lake effect flurries have developed off Georgian Bay. The activity should intensify with a threat of snow squalls overnight. Some areas may see snowfall amounts of 10 cm by Sunday morning. In addition, northwest winds gusting up to 50 km/h may result in areas of blowing snow giving reduced visibility. The lake effect activity is expected to diminish Sunday morning. Motorists are urged to exercise caution. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-05T19:39:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-05T03:58:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0939190216.2020
Area: Barrie - Collingwood - Hillsdale, Owen Sound - Blue Mountains - Northern Grey County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow beginning Sunday afternoon with snow squalls developing early Monday. Snow associated with a low pressure system will move into the area Sunday afternoon. Snowfall amounts near 10 cm are likely by early Monday morning. In the wake of this low, snow squalls will develop early Monday morning. Additional snowfall amounts of 15 cm are possible through Monday. Strong west to northwest winds gusting up to 60 km/h will result in areas of blowing snow giving reduced visibility. The snow squalls will ease late in the day on Monday. Snow squall watches or warnings are likely to be issued as the event draws near. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-05T20:42:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-05T04:43:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0380993373.2020
Area: Agawa - Lake Superior Park, Searchmont - Montreal River Harbour - Batchawana Bay, Sault Ste. Marie - St. Joseph Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls expected overnight into Monday. Snow associated with an approaching weather system will affect regions near Lake Superior this afternoon and evening with several centimetres likely. After the system passes overnight, increasing northwest winds will result in the development of lake effect flurries and snow squalls which will persist into Monday. Snowfall accumulations of 15 to 25 cm will be possible in some areas from tonight until late Monday. In addition, northwest winds gusting to 70 km/h will result in areas of blowing snow giving very poor visibility. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-06T02:07:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-05T10:08:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3079760076.2020
Area: Agawa - Lake Superior Park, Searchmont - Montreal River Harbour - Batchawana Bay, Sault Ste. Marie - St. Joseph Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. An unsettled trough of low pressure is swinging through the region and is giving snow, heavy at times to the Stewart region. 6 cm of snow has already fallen and a further 10 to 15 cm is expected to fall overnight. The heavy snow should ease by daybreak on Sunday. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-05T15:42:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-04T23:43:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3844697077.2020
Area: North Coast - inland including Stewart
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 25 to 30 cm continues. A southwest flow of moist and unstable air will continue to impact the Coquihalla Highway between Hope and Merritt today. Periods of snow may be heavy at times resulting in accumulations of up to 10 cm today and again tonight. An approaching Pacific warm front Monday will give heavier snowfall beginning early Monday morning. Further accumulations will likely exceed 15 cm during the day. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-06T05:43:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-05T13:44:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1570321747.2020
Area: Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of very cold wind chills continues. The coldest wind chill values will be between minus 55 and minus 60. Extreme cold conditions are expected to moderate by Monday morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-05T19:01:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-05T03:02:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3172017381.2020
Area: Cambridge Bay, Gjoa Haven, Kugaaruk

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Large waves, pounding surf, and elevated water levels are expected. Wave heights: near 6 metres, breaking upon approach to shore. Locations: northeast-facing shorelines on the Avalon Peninsula. Time span: near high tide early Monday morning between 2 A.M. and 6 A.M. Remarks: Minor coastal flooding is possible along shorelines exposed to the northeast near high tide. Water levels will begin to subside later Monday morning, but high waves will persist into the afternoon. Shore or beach erosion is possible in vulnerable areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-06T06:30:34-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. Snow associated with a low pressure system will move into the area late this morning and will taper off overnight. The snow may fall heavily at times, particularly this afternoon and early evening. Snowfall amounts of 15 to 20 cm are likely by the time the snow tapers off overnight. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls dissipating this morning. Lake effect snow continues near Lake Huron this morning. Some areas may see total amounts of up to 15 cm by later this morning. Northwest winds gusting up to 50 km/h may also produce areas of blowing snow giving reduced visibilities. The activity is expected to weaken later this morning. However, additional snowfall is expected to move into the region later in the day as a low pressure system approaches. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall with blowing snow is expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 40 cm. Maximum wind gusts: Northeast 60 to 80 km/h beginning Sunday evening increasing to northerly 100 km/h overnight. Locations: southeastern Newfoundland. Time span: Sunday afternoon through Monday morning. Remarks: 2 to 5 cm of snow can be expected across southeastern Newfoundland Sunday afternoon. The snow will then become heavy in the evening and persist overnight. Accumulations of 20 to 40 cm are forecast by dawn on Monday, with the highest amounts over the northeastern Avalon. Slightly lesser accumulations are expected along the southern shore and parts of the southern Avalon as the snow is expected to mix with ice pellets Sunday evening. Snow and blowing snow will result in reduced visibility which may impact Monday morning commuters. Whiteout conditions are expected over exposed areas overnight and into Monday morning. Conditions are expected to begin improve near noon on Monday. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-05T18:27:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-05T02:28:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2635814854.2020
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall with blowing snow is expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 40 cm. Maximum wind gusts: Northeast 60 to 80 km/h beginning this evening increasing to northerly 100 km/h overnight. Locations: southeastern Newfoundland. Time span: this afternoon through Monday morning. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, will develop over the Avalon and Burin Peninsulas near noon before spreading to Bonavista and Terra Nova by late this afternoon. Generally 5 cm of snow can be expected across southeastern Newfoundland this afternoon. Heavy snow will persist through tonight before diminishing Monday morning. Accumulations of 20 to 40 cm are forecast by dawn on Monday, with the highest amounts over the northeastern Avalon. Slightly lesser accumulations are expected along the southern shore and parts of the southern Avalon as the snow is expected to mix with ice pellets this evening. Snow and blowing snow will result in reduced visibility which may impact Monday morning commuters. Whiteout conditions are expected over exposed areas overnight and into Monday morning. Conditions are expected to begin improve near noon on Monday. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-06T06:32:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-05T14:33:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2887353930.2020
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula, Connaigre, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 25 cm. Locally higher amounts possible. Maximum wind gusts: 70 to 80 km/h. Locations: Eastern mainland Nova Scotia and Cape Breton. Time span: Until late this evening for accumulating snow; This afternoon until early Monday morning for strongest winds and blowing snow. Remarks: Snow will taper to flurries late this evening. Strong and gusty north to northeasterly winds will develop this afternoon and will likely give frequent reduced visibility in blowing snow tonight into Monday morning before gradually diminishing. Conditions are expected to improve Monday. ### Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-06T06:45:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-05T14:46:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2788224036.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Accumulating snow expected today. Total snowfall: total 5 to 15 cm. Time span: today into this evening. Location: central, northern and western Nova Scotia. A winter storm warning is in effect for eastern parts of the province. Remarks: A disturbance passing to the south of the Maritimes will spread snow to the province today. Snow will gradually end over western regions this afternoon but will continue into the evening over northern regions. Additionally, strong northerly winds will develop later today and combine with the fresh snow to create occasionally reduced visibility in blowing snow. Winds will diminish over most regions by early Monday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-06T06:49:12-00:00
